problem: In a math class of 30 students, 12 out of 15 girls are freshmen and 11 out of 15 boys are freshmen. What is the probability that in a randomly selected group of five students from the class, there will be two freshmen girls and three freshmen boys? Express your answer as a decimal to the nearest thousandth.
solution: We can choose 2 freshmen girls and 3 freshman boys in $\binom{12}{2}\binom{11}{3} = 10890$ ways.  There are a total of $\binom{30}{5} = 142506$ possible groups of 5 students we can choose.  Thus the probability of selecting a group of 5 students with 2 freshman girls and 3 freshmen boys is $\frac{10890}{142506} \approx \boxed{0.076}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Find the probability of selecting a freshman girl as the first student: P(GF) = 12/15 = 0.8.
Step 2: Find the probability of selecting a freshman girl as the second student, given that the first student selected was a freshman girl: P(GF|GF) = (11/15) / (14/15) = 11/14 ≈ 0.786.
Step 3: Find the probability of selecting a freshman boy as the third student, given that the first two students selected were a freshman girl and another freshman girl: P(B|GF,GF) = (11/15) / (12/15) = 11/12 ≈ 0.917
Step 4: Find the probability of selecting two freshman girls and three freshman boys in a randomly selected group of five students: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) ≈ 0.179
Step 5: Calculate the probability of the last two selections: P(FB|FB,FB) = (10/15) / (13/15) = 10/13 ≈ 0.769
Step 6: Multiply the probabilities of the first 4 steps and the last step: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) * ((10/15) / (13/15)) ≈ 0.112
Step 7: Multiply the probabilities of the first 6 steps: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) * ((10/15) / (13/15)) * (9/15) / (7/15) ≈ 0.087
Step 8: Multiply the probabilities of the first 7 steps: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) * ((10/15) / (13/15)) * (9/15) / (7/15) * (8/15) / (6/15) ≈ 0.048
Step 9: Multiply the probabilities of the first 8 steps: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) * ((10/15) / (13/15)) * (9/15) / (7/15) * (8/15) / (6/15) * (7/15) / (5/15)
Step 10: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) * ((10/15) / (13/15)) * (9/15) / (7/15) * (8/15) / (6/15) * (7/15) / (5/15) * (6/15) / (4/15)
steps: Step 1: Find the probability of selecting a freshman girl as the first student: P(GF) = 12/15 = 0.8.
Step 2: Find the probability of selecting a freshman girl as the second student, given that the first student selected was a freshman girl: P(GF|GF) = (11/15) / (14/15) = 11/14 ≈ 0.786.

Step 3: Find the probability of selecting a freshman boy as the third student, given that the first two students selected were a freshman girl and another freshman girl: P(B|GF,GF) = (11/15) / (12/15) = 11/12 ≈ 0.917

Step 4: Find the probability of selecting two freshman girls and three freshman boys in a randomly selected group of five students: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) ≈ 0.179
Step 5: Calculate the probability of the last two selections: P(FB|FB,FB) = (10/15) / (13/15) = 10/13 ≈ 0.769
full_steps: Step 1: Find the probability of selecting a freshman girl as the first student: P(GF) = 12/15 = 0.8.
Step 2: Find the probability of selecting a freshman girl as the second student, given that the first student selected was a freshman girl: P(GF|GF) = (11/15) / (14/15) = 11/14 ≈ 0.786.

Step 3: Find the probability of selecting a freshman boy as the third student, given that the first two students selected were a freshman girl and another freshman girl: P(B|GF,GF) = (11/15) / (12/15) = 11/12 ≈ 0.917

Step 4: Find the probability of selecting two freshman girls and three freshman boys in a randomly selected group of five students: P = (12/15) * ((11/15) / (14/15)) * ((11/15) / (12/15)) * ((10/15) / (10/15)) * ((9/15) / (8/15)) ≈ 0.179
Step 5: Calculate the probability of the last two selections: P(FB|FB,FB) = (10/15) / (13/15) = 10/13 ≈ 0.769
